channel.title: Const & Goto
channel.description: So I'm reading this article and it says Const and Goto are reserved but not used, why is this?

item.title: Const & Goto
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

goto:

James Gosling created the original JVM with support of goto statements, but then he removed this feature as needless. The main reason goto is unnecessary is that usually it can be replaced with more readable statements (like break/continue) or by extracting a piece of code into a method.

As well as this, using GOTO is generally considered bad practice.

const

Interestingly, the Java language specification regards const as a reserved keyword — i.e., one that cannot be used as variable identifier — but assigns no semantics to it. It is thought that the reservation of the keyword occurred to allow for an extension of the Java language to include C+±style const methods and pointer to const type. The enhancement request ticket in the Java Community Process for implementing const correctness in Java was closed in 2005, implying that const correctness will probably never find its way into the official Java specification.

Assuming you’re talking about Java.

Read full topic
